item.title: NASA, Axiom Space rework assembly of commercial space station - News9 LIVE
item.description:
NASA and Axiom Space Redesign Plans for Commercial Space Station Assembly

Publication Date: New Delhi

Source: Science News

Axiom Space, in collaboration with NASA, has updated its assembly plans for its commercial space station to expedite the process and minimize dependence on the International Space Station (ISS). The restructured plans aim to establish a free-flying commercial destination ahead of the ISS's planned retirement in 2030.

  • The revised strategy involves launching the Payload, Power, and Thermal modules towards the ISS by 2028, marking the inception of the Axiom Station.
  • Axiom's modified assembly will include an airlock and additional habitat modules after departing from the ISS.
  • NASA will maintain its scientific experiments in partnership with Axiom Space throughout this transition.
  • Other commercial projects like Boeing’s Orbital Reef and Starlab's initiatives are underway, ensuring ongoing missions in Low Earth Orbit.
“The revised plans allow Axiom Space to depart from the ISS earlier, ensuring that the ISS can stick to its planned deorbit timelines.”

This strategic shift underscores the acceleration of commercial space exploration and the necessary adjustment as international cooperation in orbit transforms.

item.title: 7 'Best of International Space Station images' 2024 shared by NASA - India.com
item.description:
7 'Best of International Space Station images' 2024 shared by NASA

Publication Date: December 22, 2024 | Source: India.com

Nasa has shared a collection of stunning images taken from the International Space Station, showcasing remarkable sights from space.

  • Eclipse and Soyuz MS-25: Capturing a total solar eclipse over Mexico, the United States, and Canada.
  • Lysozyme crystals from the ADSEP-PIL-02 investigation: Showcasing space-grown lysozyme crystals.
  • Long-exposure photograph of auroras and city lights by astronaut Don Pettit.
  • Red sprites captured by astronaut Matthew Dominick.
  • Waxing lunar crescent illuminated by sunlight, with earthshine reflecting onto it.
  • Arctic region of Canada photographed by astronaut Loral O’Hara.
  • Comet C/2023 A3 (Tsuchinshan-ATLAS) viewed from above the South Atlantic Ocean.
“These images reflect the incredible beauty and scientific importance of space exploration,” said NASA officials.

These breathtaking images not only highlight the work of astronauts but also inspire interest in space and science.

item.title: NASA recreates asteroid Vesta in lab to investigate mysterious gullies - News9 LIVE
item.description:
NASA Recreates Asteroid Vesta in Lab to Study Mysterious Gullies

Publication Date: New Delhi

Source: Science News

NASA’s Dawn spacecraft discovered mysterious flow formations on Asteroid Vesta in 2011. Now, scientists are investigating these features by recreating the asteroid in a lab.

  • The Dawn spacecraft orbited Vesta from July 2011 to September 2012.
  • Gullies on the asteroid might be formed by salty water flows or brine.
  • Dry debris flows may occur due to meteoroid impacts or temperature changes.
  • Researchers used the DUSTIE chamber at JPL to simulate meteoroid impacts.
  • Salty water can flow longer before freezing than pure water.
“While pure water freezes instantly on exposure to vacuum, brine or salty water can flow for some time before freezing.”

The study aims to better understand the processes contributing to the formation of gullies and the potential for liquid water on asteroids like Vesta.

item.title: Set For A Close Call? 120-Foot Asteroid To Whiz By Earth On Christmas Eve - News18
item.description:
120-Foot Asteroid Set to Fly By Earth on Christmas Eve

Date: December 22, 2024 Source: News18

NASA has revealed that a massive 120-foot asteroid, named 2024 XN1, will fly past Earth on December 24 at a safe distance of 4,480,000 miles. This close encounter provides an opportunity for scientists to study asteroids and their origins.

  • The asteroid travels at a high speed of 14,743 kilometers per hour.
  • NASA reassures that there is no immediate threat to Earth from this asteroid.
  • This flyby serves as a reminder of the importance of planetary defense mechanisms.
  • A total of five asteroids are expected to approach Earth in a similar timeframe.
  • Nasa's Asteroid Watch provides tracking details for close-approaching asteroids.
“An object larger than about 150 metres that can approach the Earth to within this distance is termed a potentially hazardous object.”

In conclusion, while 2024 XN1 poses no danger, NASA emphasizes the need for ongoing monitoring of such space rocks to better understand the solar system and mitigate potential future threats.

item.title: Parker Solar Probe begins record-setting dive into Solar Corona - News9 LIVE
item.description:
Parker Solar Probe Begins Historic Approach to the Sun

Publication Date: 24 December 2024 | Source: Science News

The Parker Solar Probe is set to make history as it approaches within 6.1 million kilometers of the Sun, breaking its own record.

  • The spacecraft will conduct the closest approach to the Sun ever on 24 December 2024.
  • This record surpasses the previous closest distance of 6.3 million kilometers achieved in July 2023.
  • The probe's systems are reported to be in good health ahead of the flyby.
  • Ground teams will regain contact with the probe after it transmits a health beacon on 27 December.
  • NASA’s mission aims to provide insights into solar processes and enhance understanding of space weather.
“This is one example of NASA’s bold missions, doing something that no one else has ever done before to answer longstanding questions about our universe.” - Arik Posner, Parker Solar Probe Program Scientist

This mission not only has immediate scientific significance but also promises to shape future research on solar phenomena.

item.title: NASA, SpaceX to launch IMAP heliophysics mission in September 2025 - News9 LIVE
item.description:
NASA and SpaceX to Launch IMAP Mission in September 2025

Date: October 2023 Source: News9 Live

Nasa and SpaceX are now aiming for the launch of the Interstellar Mapping and Acceleration Probe (IMAP) spacecraft in September 2025. The revised schedule allows for better preparation for the mission, which will explore the heliosphere and provide insights into energetic particles that affect human space exploration.

  • IMAP will analyze and map particles streaming toward Earth from the heliosphere.
  • In addition to IMAP, two other heliophysics observatories will launch in 2025.
  • The observatories will help monitor solar activity and its effects on Earth.
  • All missions are targeted for the first Lagrange point (L1) for efficient monitoring of the Sun.
“These energetic particles can impact human explorers in flares, damage hardware, and is believed to play a role in the presence of life in the universe.”

The launch will utilize a Falcon 9 rocket from Cape Canaveral Space Force Station, streamlining the process for deploying multiple missions.

item.title: Ursid Meteor Shower Peaks: Here's how to watch the final celestial show of 2024 - The Economic Times
item.description:
Ursid Meteor Shower Peaks: Here's How to Watch the Final Celestial Show of 2024

Publication Date: December 22, 2024

Source: Agencies

The Ursid meteor shower will peak on December 22, 2024, offering a chance to see up to 10 meteors per hour for stargazing enthusiasts. Despite the moon's brightness potentially hindering visibility, the shower presents a notable opportunity, especially in the Northern Hemisphere.

Key Points

  • The peak of the Ursid meteor shower is expected between 4 and 5 a.m. ET on December 22.
  • The meteors originate from comet 8P/Tuttle.
  • Observers are encouraged to face north and find a dark location away from artificial lights.
  • Despite challenging visibility due to the moon, stargazers can still see a few meteors early in the morning.
  • For those who miss this event, the Quadrantids meteor shower will peak shortly after on January 3, 2025.

Notable Quotes

“To best see these meteors, face toward the north with the moon behind you.” - Robert Lunsford

“Up to 10 meteors may be visible per hour... but expect only five per hour this year due to the bright moon.” - Robert Lunsford

Conclusion

The Ursid meteor shower provides a unique opportunity to witness a celestial event as 2024 comes to a close, even with some challenges posed by moonlight.

item.title: NASA Warns Of Big 120-ft Asteroid To Come Alarmingly Close To Earth On Christmas Eve: Will It Hit? - Times Now
item.description:
NASA Warns Of Big 120-ft Asteroid To Come Alarmingly Close To Earth On Christmas Eve: Will It Hit?

Date: December 24, 2024 Source: Times Now

This Christmas Eve, NASA has identified a fast-moving asteroid named 2024 XN1, measuring 120 feet across, which will make a close pass by Earth.

  • The asteroid is expected to pass on December 24 at 8:27 am IST.
  • 2024 XN1 will come within 7,220,000 kilometres of Earth.
  • It is traveling at a speed of 23,729 km/h.
  • This asteroid is not considered a threat as it is smaller than 150 meters and passes outside of hazardous range.
  • NASA monitors asteroids using a network of telescopes and the NEOWISE space telescope.
“Thanks to NASA’s vigilant tracking system, asteroid 2024 XN1’s flyby will be just another fascinating celestial event — nothing to fear!”

This event serves as a reminder of the importance of monitoring near-Earth objects for potential threats.

item.title: 7 Rare images of Helix Nebula shared by NASA - India.com
item.description:
7 Rare Images of Helix Nebula Shared by NASA

Publication Date: December 2024 Source: India.com

The article showcases seven stunning images of the Helix Nebula, released by NASA, illustrating its beauty and complexity through various perspectives and enhancements.

  • Spiral Beauty: A wide-angle shot showcasing intricate spiral patterns.
  • The "Eye of God": A close-up view highlighting the nebula's striking blue center.
  • Ultraviolet Majesty: A UV-enhanced image revealing the central star's brightness.
  • Outer Halo Focus: A zoomed-out image showing the faint outer halos of gas.
  • 3D Simulation View: A simulated view offering a glimpse into the nebula's complex structure.
  • Infrared Glow: An infrared image revealing hidden layers of dust and gas.
  • Composite Imagery: A multi-wavelength image displaying the nebula in full spectrum.
"Thanks For Reading!"

This collection of images not only highlights the aesthetic appeal of the Helix Nebula but also demonstrates the advancements in astronomical imaging and our understanding of such celestial phenomena.

item.title: 7 Colourful Pictures Of Universe Captured By NASA - Times Now
item.description:
7 Colourful Pictures Of Universe Captured By NASA

Publication Date: Dec 22, 2024 | Source: Times Now

This article showcases stunning images of the universe captured by NASA, highlighting various celestial phenomena.

  • Revisiting a Celestial Fireworks Display: A supernova remnant captured by Hubble reveals intricate patterns from a massive star's death.
  • NGC 6302: A planetary nebula resembling a butterfly, illuminated by ultraviolet light.
  • Mystic Mountain: A striking image of a gas and dust pillar reminiscent of a scene from a fantasy novel.
  • Cloaked In Red: A view of young stars forming in the Large Magellanic Cloud.
  • V838 Monocerotis Revisited: An image featuring dust spirals reflecting van Gogh's style.
  • The Eagle Has Risen: A towering column of gas and dust known as the Eagle Nebula.
  • The Twin Jet Nebula: A unique bipolar planetary nebula formed from a binary system.
“These stunning images provide a glimpse into the dynamic and colorful universe we inhabit.”

These images serve as a reminder of the beauty and complexity of the universe beyond our planet.

item.title: Study says lunar water can be from meteorite or comet, hints at link between Moon & Earth - ThePrint
item.description:
Study says lunar water can be from meteorite or comet, hints at link between Moon & Earth

Publication Date: Recent

Source: PNAS Journal

A new study sheds light on the origins of water on the Moon, suggesting it may have come from meteorites and comets, linking the Moon's formation to Earth's early development.

  • The study proposes two main origins for lunar water: from meteorites connected to Early Earth's formation and comets impacting the Moon.
  • Researchers utilized triple oxygen isotope analysis of lunar dust from Apollo samples to draw their conclusions.
  • Enstatite chondrites are identified as a significant contributor to lunar water, also linked to water formation on Earth.
“This study helps us understand more about the origins of water, an essential life component, on the lunar surface.”

This groundbreaking research enhances our understanding of lunar conditions and may inform future studies on Moon habitation.

item.title: James Webb telescope solves 20-year-old Hubble conundrum — and it could finally explain why the universe's oldest planets exist - Livescience.com
item.description:
James Webb telescope solves 20-year-old Hubble conundrum — and it could finally explain why the universe's oldest stars host massive planets

Publication Date: December 16, 2023 | Source: Live Science

The James Webb Space Telescope has resolved a longstanding mystery regarding how ancient stars could support the existence of large planets. This breakthrough helps to clarify the conditions in the early universe that allowed for planet formation.

  • The JWST's findings confirm Hubble's observations of ancient massive planets.
  • Research published in The Astrophysical Journal indicates that planetary disks around early stars could last longer than initially thought.
  • This revelation alters the understanding of planet formation in environments with few heavy elements.
“We see that these stars are indeed surrounded by disks and are still in the process of gobbling material, even at the relatively old age of 20 [million] or 30 million years,” said Guido De Marchi, study lead author.

This research opens new avenues for understanding the architecture of planetary systems in the early universe and the conditions that foster their development.

item.title: 7 stunning cosmology photos captured by Hubble Space Telescope of NASA - India.Com
item.description:
7 Stunning Cosmology Photos from Hubble Space Telescope

Publication Date: December 21, 2024

Source: India.com

This article showcases breathtaking images captured by NASA's Hubble Space Telescope, highlighting various celestial phenomena.

  • Celestial Fireworks:

    DEM L 190, known as LMC N49, is the brightest supernova remnant in the Large Magellanic Cloud, lying around 160,000 light-years from Earth.

  • Einstein Ring:

    GAL-CLUS-022058s is one of the largest and most complete Einstein rings discovered in the universe.

  • Fornax 2:

    A globular cluster in the dwarf galaxy Fornax, showcasing similarities to clusters found in the Milky Way.

  • Star Jets:

    A Herbig-Haro object named HH111 was captured by Hubble's Wide Field Camera 3.

  • Cosmic Discolights:

    An image of the galaxy cluster MACS J0717.5+3745, highlighting dark matter.

  • Dark Matter:

    The galaxy cluster Abell 383 shows the effects of dark matter mass bending light from distant objects.

  • Massive Gamma-ray Burst:

    Observations of gamma-ray burst GRB 190114C, first detected in January 2019.
"These observations from Hubble provide critical insights into the processes occurring in our universe, showcasing the beauty and complexity of cosmic events."

The photos captured by the Hubble Space Telescope not only deepen our understanding of the cosmos but also inspire awe at the wonders of the universe.

item.title: Researchers reveal how human eyelashes encourage water drainage - Daily News Egypt
item.description:
Researchers reveal how human eyelashes encourage water drainage

Date: December 20, 2023 Source: Science Advances

This study reveals the unique hydrodynamic properties of human eyelashes, demonstrating their role in maintaining clean eyesight by effectively draining excess moisture.

  • Eyelashes are composed of a flexible array of hydrophobic fibers.
  • They facilitate the rapid removal of moisture from the eyes, preserving visual acuity.
  • Research was conducted by a team from the Chinese Academy of Sciences.
  • A quantitative model was created to understand the elastic forces affecting eyelash function.
  • The findings may inspire the design of new waterproof devices and aesthetic products.
“The mechanism governing moisture drainage is due to the fiber array’s heterogeneous elastic deformations and multi-scale asymmetric structures.” - Prof. JIANG Lei

This research enhances our understanding of the functional significance of eyelashes, suggesting they play an essential role in eye care during activities like exercise.

item.title: Moon was formed around 4.51 billion years ago: study - The Hindu
item.description:
Moon was formed around 4.51 billion years ago: study

Published on: December 21, 2024 - Source: Nature

New research indicates that the Moon may have formed approximately 4.51 billion years ago, challenging previous estimates of 4.35 billion years due to a remelting event that obscured its older history.

  • The Moon formed from a giant impact between early Earth and a Mars-sized protoplanet.
  • Previous estimations of the Moon's age relied on lunar rock samples, but discrepancies suggest an older formation.
  • Researchers argue that the frequent presence of 4.35-billion-year-old rocks could be due to a remelting event rather than the initial solidification of the magma ocean.
  • The remelting could explain the lack of early lunar impact basins.
  • This new analysis aligns with our understanding of planet formation and suggests the Moon's creation occurred between 4.43 and 4.53 billion years ago.
The formation of the Moon occurred between 4.43 and 4.53 billion years ago, at the upper limit of previous age estimates.

This study provides vital insights into the Moon's formation and its alignment with terrestrial planet formation theories.

item.title: Scientists observe ‘negative time’ in quantum experiments - Macau Business
item.description:
Scientists Discover 'Negative Time' in Quantum Mechanics

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Macau Business

Researchers at the University of Toronto have observed a phenomenon they describe as 'negative time,' shedding light on complex interactions between light and matter.

  • The term ‘negative time’ refers to the duration of excited states in atoms being measured as less than zero.
  • Experiments took over two years to optimize and involved lasers and atoms.
  • The findings challenge conventional understanding but do not imply time travel.
  • The research has garnered both skepticism and intrigue within the scientific community.
“We don’t want to say anything traveled backward in time,” said Aephraim Steinberg, a lead researcher.

The discovery highlights the complexities of quantum mechanics and may pave the way for further exploration of light and time.
